Early Access Review
								Recreational activities in virtual reality... a very simple concept, that is much more fun than you might expect! Controls:The controls in Rec Room are very simple and intuitive. Touchpad = Teleport, Trigger = Grab, Menu Button = Menu. That's literally all that you need to know to play this game! Graphics/Animation:The graphics in this game are very cartoonish and simple, But that is NOT a bad thing. The game is very polished and detailed and contains everything you would want from a VR title. The animations in this game are wonderful! They were very well thought out and designed. Everything moves around smoothly, and there are lots of little details that make this game great!Physics:The physics are great, until they are not, but when they are not, there were not supposed to be. All of the games physics work perfectly and smoothly, except for the darts. That's where things get fun. In the main lobby, throwing darts onto objects causes some weird things to occur such as making the object float, or spin. This is all apart of the fun though! The few physics that don't work, don't need to work, and if they did, the game just wouldn't be the same. Multiplayer: This is the main feature of the game, and it is portrayed PERFECTLY! All the small aspects of this game is what makes it so great! Want to join a party with someone? Give them a fist bump! Don't want anyone to hear you sneeze in real life? Put your in-game hand over your mouth to mute your mic! Genius! Most people that play this game tend to be pretty nice. Remember though, this is still the internet, you WILL run into some pretty impolite, no mannered, idiots occasionally. Prepare for explicit language and sexual content. If someone can say it/do it, you can hear it/see it.Customization:You can make your Rec Room avatar look any way that you want it to! There are many different items and accessories including; Shirts, wristbands, glasses, hair bands/bows, gloves, sweatbands, and more! Lots of hair style options are available, and you can change them to any (Natural) hair color. Skin color is also an option!The settings page lets you change just about everything to make the game perfect for you! Resolution too low? Turn it up! Someone talking about something you don't want to hear, or even screaming in their mic? Mute them. Simple. There are TONS of options for voice chat. This even includes a voice changer! Three different options are included for when you want people to hear you. Always On, Push-To-Talk (Grip Button to activate), and Off. Graphics and mic customization are just a few of the settings Rec Room has to offer, so play around with them until they work for you!Games:6 games are currently available to play in Rec Room; Dodgeball, PaintBall, 3D Charades, Disc Golf, Soccer, and Paddle Ball. All of which, are not only as fun as the real thing, but as REAL as the real thing. Each game is totally unique and fun in its own way! None of these games can be played by yourself (while still having fun), they all need two or more people to really complete the experience. (They are multiplayer games in real life after all.) All 6 games allow you to use your mic to communicate with each other. Whether your joking around and having a good time in 3D Charades, or Talking with your team and strategically planning your next Paintball round! Make sure you try out all of the different games, as they are all very fun, unique, and competitive (If you want it to be!).Tips and Tricks:1. You can reorientate your room by squeezing the grip button on both controllers!2. While holding an object with the trigger, you can press the top menu button to lock it in place. Now you no longer have to hold the trigger down! Rec Room is updated almost weekly with new features! It's a free application, which honestly feels like I am scamming the developers of their time and money! Please download this game right now, you waisted time reading this review when you could have been playing the game already! :)9.5/10EDIT: After 50 hours of playtime, I have to change my rating...10/10

								Consider for a moment how life was before celluar phones and broadband internet, if you wanted to do something with others, you would generally find yourself slumming it at the local recreation center. That's what this game brings you back to, spending time with strangers doing social things. And this way you don't have to worry about seeing that old guy naked in the locker rooms, or wonder if you might get kidnapped by that creepy guy with the trenchcoat. Not to mention the wide variety of games for everyone: Charades for those times when your word is Robin Hood, and everyone in the room keeps guessing a camel because you're awful at drawing; Paintball, for all those times you wanted to know how poorly you'd do in a real fps; Ping Pong, because it wasn't frustrating enough in real life so now you get to chase a ping pong ball accross two floors; Dodgeball, so you can experience what it was like to be the fat kid during PE. Now the servers don't seem to have the greatest connection sometimes people's voices might lag, or they'll slowly start to drift off into the sky, but this is the new generation of chat rooms, and it looks... very positive. With vr you get this extra level of communication, though rudimentary, there's real body language being transmitted, and that's honestly very cool with such a positive community in this currently. This is the Wii sports of VR, as in, this game by itself, makes your purchase feel worth it.

								Rec Room has been one of my top 3 games to play in VR ever since I got my HTC Vive!  For the price, you get a heft amount of content plus I love the incentives you have for coming back such as the allure of new items.  I noticed the locker room area also has some renovations coming soon so it's nice to see the devs adding more content.  The basic gist of the game is that you have a few main areas: Your dorm room is where you customize your character and just fool around getting used to the controls and such.  The locker room is the lobby of sorts where people from around the world congregate and fool around with basketballs, frisbees, darts, ping pong, punching dummies, dodgeballs, boomboxes, etc.  You can talk to people if you like and it's nice to see features such as being able to mute yourself and others just in case things get a bit annoying.  The other areas are the main meat of the game which are the Rec Room activities.  You've got various things to choose from: dodgeball, disc golf, 3D charades, paintball, shield soccer, and paddle ball.  My favorite activities to play are dodgeball and paintball, they are both great for a workout because of all the dodging and ducking you'll be doing!  The games themselves, from what I've seen, typically have very friendly and fun people playing them so there's no need to feel socially anxious about joining a game with strangers.  There is one last area which was recently added and it's a private lounge which you can relax in alone or you can invite friends and other players.  Inside the private lounge, you'll find a dart board, ping pong table, dice, a card table, a boombox, a conference room complete with whiteboards, and a 3D charades stage.All in all, this is one of the best examples I've played as far as AAA virtual reality games are concerned because the polish and attention to detail is high with Rec Room and the replay value is very high especially due to the social aspect of it since it's online.  If you have a VR headset, Rec Room needs to be in your library!Checkout my playthrough of a couple Rec Room games!

								A few par-for-the-course early access bugs notwithstanding, this is an impressively polished and super fun social VR title! The environments, soundtrack, and the aesthetic of the avatars all set a playful and welcoming tone. Fist bumping to party up with others is charmingly intuitive, and who doesn't love high fives with confetti?! The integration of equipable video cameras is a clever addition to a social space like this, adding another way to interact beyond playing the game modes proper or tossing around toys.Of the games currently included, my favorite is paddle ball. It's ridiculously fun getting into a heated one-on-one volley exchange. Make sure you're secure with your chaperone and have cleared plenty of space for exuberant swinging, as the matches do get intense!The only issues I've encountered so far have been a bit of judder in the lobby occasionally, and some minor glitchy behavior related to avatar customization. The sports themselves run remarkably solid though, with no noticeable lag or major physics weirdness. Voice chat is clear and loud, perhaps working *too* well with more boisterous chatters in the area, but individuals can thankfully be muted. Teleportation is nicely implemented, with an aiming arch and helpful preview of your avatar's warp location.If you have a Vive, don't hesitate to give this one a go. At its current price of FREE you are getting an incredible value. I'd have unquestionably thrown some cash towards this, and still would as it becomes more robust with time.

Early Access Review
								A Motion Controller exclusive Altspace Alternative, Free to Play, and highly recommended.If you haven't played Altspace, make sure to try that too, if you have played it, don't hold on to preconceptions when you try out this game. Both of them offer a similar experience: interact with REAL people in fun VR activities, but both have advantages and disadvantages, and a completely different style to their entire experience.The most up front difference: Rec Room is a much more exclusive experience. From the ground up, not only is Rec Room exclusively PC VR, but also seems to be designed in such a way that it is impossible to play properly without a pair of motion controllers. I recently had to send in a Vive Wand for repair and have been getting by with minor difficulty using my remaining Wand, but am left at a handicap for nearly every aspect of the game.Whether this is good or bad is still to be seen. On one hand, I personally like the concept of an experience that as many people as possible are capable of enjoying, but I can't help but notice that the interactions with people who have thrown down the $3000+ for the PC VR tech have been much more enjoyable overall compared to those with the people who only invested an extra $100-$400 for their GearVR.I'm not going to chalk this up to a straight Poor vs Rich issue though, in fact the people who use GearVR due to fiscial necessity are far more pleasant. I'm more inclined to treat this as an issue of focus; people who play VR on the PC have had to make purchases SPECIFICALLY for the VR itself. It is something they had to deliberately seek out and aquire for the purpose of VR. Other users generally don't seem as invested in VR as an experience and see it more as an afterthought.Next big difference is that even though it is listed as early access, Rec Room feels like a much more finished experience. Altspace feels like it is constantly under development, features are being added, bugs and glitches are being squashed, and developers/admins are right in the thick of things taking feedback directly and using that to improve the experience. I haven't noticed any place within the game where a developer could be directly contacted, but I also haven't noticed any particular issue that I felt needed to be reported to a developer either. There are certainly exploits that creative use of room scale can allow, but there also seems to be much fewer actual glitches that I've noticed, and if anything the exploits only add to the opportunity to step outside of the conventions of reality.The aesthetic style of Rec Room nearly had me quit in the first 5 minutes. The avatars feel like they should be in a facebook game, and make me wish I could create a Nintendo Mii instead. Everything from the hairstyles, the shirts, and all the accessories all seem deliberatley chosen to be the tackiest possible fashion, regardless of whether you're judging from a realistic standpoint or a gaming geek standpoint. Still, the physical model options are much more varied than what alspace currently offers (currently less than half a dozen distinct models and only the abilty to vary 2 different colors on most of them)Style is subjective, so maybe someone else will find RecRoom's style to their liking, or at least less detestable.The different activities that Rec Room offers come out much more polished, and a lot of this may simply go back to the initial point that Rec room is a motion controller exclusive. Most of Altspace's activities are accessible to even Gear VR users (some don't work well for them) but result in very simple static experiences like playing tabletop or card based games. Rec Room's experiences are much more physical and interactive, such as paddleball, disc golf, 3d charades, soccer, and paintball. There are also daily activites to complete for XP, which help encourage players to at least try out the different experiences available. If you want to try anything besides paintball, you'll want to keep an eye on these activities, as you have a much higher chance of finding other players in these games when they are listed as an activity. I'll take a moment to talk about each of the different activities below:Paintball is undoubtedly the biggest draw in Rec room. I have never seen less than 4 players on any individual map, and there are 3 maps to choose from. You also will almost certainly wind up going up against someone who has played longer and can completely destroy you. Some sort of behind the scenes match making would be great here, but not any type of leaderboard, or people will take things far too seriously. Taking a bad run of hits is already frustrating, but I can only imagine how obnoxious it would be to have my own team shouting at me for dragging them down.I would say my next favorite game is actually 3D charades, which is actually a combination of Charades and a 3D pictionary. You can draw crude physical shapes, but then also move yourself and gesture in order to add to the experience. This is a game that relies entirely on the honor system though. You can hit the button to say that people guess correctly even if they didn't, but you could do the same with real charades too.Disc golf is next on my list. On one hand, I don't like the throwing mechanics, as the unntural flight mechanics of the frisbee make it incredibly difficult to predict how you need to throw. Anyone who has thrown a real frisbee or disc will almost certainly despise this VR version. However it does offer one of the most interesting expeirences if you play with more players. After a disc is thrown, other players are capable of hitting the disc. While this might be seen as a bug that needs to be stamped out to prevent griefing, it does carry with it the ability to help block the disc from falling into a water hazard or going to far past the goal on a missed throw. Again, this is a case where in real life, people CAN do this, so it's not entirely clear if this even SHOULD be stamped out.Paddle Ball is a two player experience, and doesn't seem to get much draw. Though you start a game with a raquet, it actually plays easier and faster by dropping the raquet and hitting the ball with your hand, making the experience similar to a 3D pong or air hockey game. Well recommended, provided you have someone to play with, so definitely wait until it's a daily activity to try it out, and just ask people if they're interested in friending up to play later.Soccer almost plays like a teleporting rocket(less) league. It is team based, but you'll be lucky to get a second player even with it being listed as a daily activity. Teleporting is both the method of moving around, as well as the method of striking the ball. It can be very disorienting to play, and frequently the ball can be hit at a speed that is just too fast to catch up to, so defense in a 1 vs 1 game can be incredibly difficult. This is another one that really needs to wait for it to be listed as a daily activity to try out.You can also find camcorders strewn about the area, which can be picked up to record actual video capture to your PC. There might be other activities, but that's all that I have stumbled across to this point. If I see anything new, I'll come back and add it to the list, but regardless of what is added in the future, even just the current list of experiences is well worth the download for anyone with a Vive or Oculus Touch.

								Simply put, Rec Room is the most fun I've had with any VR game. Rec Room takes everything that is fun about VR games and combines them.The online connectivity is almost flawless. When you log on, you are instantly and seamlessly dropped into an online multiplayer lobby with complete strangers, and you'll be able to interact with them immediatly. Talk to strangers, play mini-games with them, and get to know them.The physical aspect of the game is brilliant as well. Some games have you stand still, which doesn't get you very much exercise. Some games have you dancing around and moving like crazy, which can wear you out very quickly and make you need to stop playing. I'm a physically fit and active person, but I can't play a game like Audioshield or Holopoint for more than 30-60 minutes before becoming too tired and having to take my headset off. Rec Room however, for the most part involves only light physical activity, which feels good and doesn't wear you out too quickly. I played various mini-games in Rec Room for 5 hours straight before stopping.The real magic of this game is the conversations you will have with people you've never met before. I spent 2 hours playing frisbee golf with a couple from North Carolina, and by the end of the night I felt like I knew them on a real and personal basis. That was an experience I've never had from a video game before. There are more things I could say about my love of Rec Room, but I'll just leave you with this statement. Rec Room is, to me, what I dreamed of from virtual reality. I can log on at any time and I will have fun, make friends, get exercise, and be happy. No other game can deliver all of that to you. If you have a VR headset, this game is a MUST TRY. And hey, it's free so you don't have an excuse not to give it a try.

The other people immediately taught me everything that I didn't figure out myself. The whole multiplayer experience was seamless and instantaneous for me. I quickly found my way to the paintball area and played a few matches of capture the flag. Again, you just jump right in, and learn as you go. I quickly stopped noticing the simplicity of the graphics and was just playing paintball. You teleport around a lot, but it still felt like regular paintball tactics worked. The "gun" could use more vibration for immersion, but otherwise I can't see any obvious flaws. Great experience so far!

Early Access Review
								Fantastic. This should be worth _at least_ 5$ just for the paintball. This game is basically Wii Sports: VR:, and thats a ton more fun than it sounds. You can play paintball and other games you will try and never play again, because paintball is so good. Its fun, tactical, and has a great community (for the most part) of adults and children alike having a blast. The game is a perfect fit for VR: Grabbing guns, balls, and cameras with your Vive or Oculus hand controllers (Wands and Touch respectivly) feels very responsive and intuitive. Items are also importance-sensitive: Meaning, you either need to constantly hold down the grab button (balls, markers, etc.) or just press once and let it stick (guns), which is a fantastic way to do things. The dorm room and leveling systems are icing on the painball-flavored cake: Its a cool personal space to relax before heading off. Even the menu is awesome: Just look to your left hand as if checking ones watch, and there you go. Menu, always at the ready. In short, this game is an absolute steal for the low, low price of nothing, and a true VR must have. A note, though: The default Oculus touch setup is insufficent here: You can turn with the thumbsticks, but you often get too caught up in the action to remember to turn. The 2 camera 360 or 3 camera roomscale is strongly advised.
